text:
Brilliant explanation by Dr. Tyson. Loved Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey and Possible Worlds and a great continuation of what Sagan started in the 1980’s. 

One way I like to think of climate change is a roller coaster analogy. Typically throughout the year the seasons change. The hottest time of the year is summer and the coldest time of the year is winter. (Obviously) So let’s say we smooth out the daily temperature swings. So it’s a month to month or season to season variation. Let’s say the roller coaster is going up and down by 5 feet. You can see the tracks behind you which represents the temperatures recoded but you can’t see what’s ahead. Roller Coaster may go up 5 feet (represents the heat in summer) and go down 5 feet (represents the cold of winter) however the roller coaster increased by 2 inches after every cycle (one year) but that rate increases by double every 5 years (so 4in to 8in to 16in etc) this represents the increase speed of climate feedbacks. You don’t really notice a change because your going up and down 5 feet through the seasons yet it’s increasing by inches. But over time you look back and start to notice your slightly higher up. You notice you can see more things in the distance. 

It’s like that with climate change. Yes you get seasons, sometime seasons are colder than normal sometimes warmer than normal. Even with a steadily increasing average, day to day weather and season changes make hard to know an increase in climate temperatures. The coldest time of year in many locations is as much as 40°F colder than the hottest time of year and even bigger if you say have a hot summer. And your only warming up at a rate of 0.5°F per decade. BUT the rate of warming increases and you start notice the climate is warmer and the effects of a warmer climate: more extreme precipitation (dry or wet), hotter longer summers, warmer shorter winters, less frequent but more intense snow storms. less frequent but more intense hurricanes, melting ice craps, higher sea levels, etc. 

By the end of the century I suspect most locations will still get cold winter and hot in summer but both seasons will be much warmer.

text:
Neil, averaging weather data flattens the graph, but only if you show it on the same short term time scale you use for weather. Show the climate graph for climate time-scales and it looks just as chaotic and jumpy as the short term weather graph. Climate is indeed more predictable than weather - if you predict climate for weather time periods. Yes, the climate tomorrow or next week will be the same as today. But that's as trivial as it is useless. We dont ask what's the climate next week, we ask what's the climate in 30 years or more. 

So your dog-on-leash-on-the-beach parabel shows nothing relevant. 

As for predictability of climate versus weather, you failed to mention two very important factors for climate change: ocean oscillations and ecosphere feedbacks. Maybe youre right and climate is indeed easier to predict (for climate time-scales) as weather (on weather time-scales) but the proof has yet to be done. Id say it isnt because - as you explained - climate is weather averaged over space and time. Averaging chaotic and unpredictable weather data doesnt make it better predictable.

text:
@JGlennFL - The 97% number isn't an opinion poll, it's an inquiry of the peer reviewed scientific papers on climate change from 2014 to 2016, of which 97% reached the conclusion that humans are causing climate change. Opinion polls are usually avoided in science because opinions have no real truth value. 

One thing republicans do is use the other 3% to prove the science isn't settled, but this is fallacious because the other 3% aren't claiming climate change is false, they just don't reach the conclusion that it's true... there's a HUGE difference; in fact, out of the 10,000s of peer reviewed scientific papers on climate change, there was only 1 peer reviewed paper written by a Russian scientists which claimed climate change was false, and that paper was retracted decades ago.

author: CTobias Clary

text: I will see your subtle innuendo and raise it. (http://www.brainpickings.org/2014/01/03/baloney-detection-kit-carl-sagan/).  Never forget that all scientific models are based on a lot of assumptions.  The .Gov link fails to identify that, which immediately calls their credibility into question.  I have had the opportunity to work with a few of these in my career and still do every so often. A few facts.... Climate change is real. It has been for 4 billion years. There have been as many "models;"  quite a few have proven it is unpredictable.  Models from 40 years ago were wrong; most of the models in use now will be abandoned in 40 years.  The guy in the video is an idiot and is trying too hard to be Carl Sagan.
author: jusTodd

text:
I will overlook the fact that you're dissing my current favorite media-savvy Nerd Lord,  @todd comer  *grumpy eyes* and will instead tackle the assumptions implied in your own argument: I in no way intend to say that Climate Change is either a new phenomenon OR entirely created by the mechanations of Mankind; instead, I mean to rebut the most commonly-floated "Common Sense" argument against CC -- "It's a really cold winter, ergo Climate Change is a lie."
I do agree that our modelling has come a looooong way in the past forty years, primarily due to our deepening understanding of the pre-existing planetary rhythms. (keep in mind, we've only had a solid weather satellite network for, what, twenty years?)
Did Man do it? Nope, but we CERTAINLY sped it up. To maintain otherwise is to be intentionally disingenuous.

Also, Carl Sagan was the sh!t and if you disagree, we can meet by the bike racks after practice...
author: CTobias Clary

text:
Indeed.  Sagan was the Einstein of his era.  That excerpt is from my favorite book of his, which validated what so many of his contemporaries are now trying to quash. Science is all about skepticism; minus that, it is only another religion.  Models will continue to evolve as long as we remain skeptical.  It is of utmost importance, especially in the climate change discussion. 

(ps... Landsat went online in 1972 - thus my 40 year reference... Oh, and sorry to diss the dork... something about him just screams fraud, to me... just can't quite put my finger on it)

author: Dwight Hannah

text:
I don't think that isn't a proper explaination.
Science IS a Democracy in terms of scientists presenting their ideas and hypothesis to their peers. The "voting" is the testing and testing again of said hypothesis, and if the hypothesis holds up, it's considered a Theory (a model if you want to use layman's terms) that stands scrutiny. Healthy skepticism is part of the process. But in the end it wrings out what is happening.

Yes, we know the sun will die, we're just not solid on the life span... that is still in debate. Same with us figuring out how to properly date planet Earth's age. It's through the collaboration of scientists, a wholly democratic process, they come to a consensus that stands up to scrutiny.

text:
Traducción al español; 

"De acuerdo, si los científicos somos tan buenos haciendo predicciones del clima a largo plazo, ¿cómo podemos ser tan malos prediciendo el tiempo? Además, este año, tenemos un invierno más frío en mi pueblo. Como los científicos lo saben, podríamos estar yendo hacia un enfriamiento global. Aquí está diferencia entre el clima y el tiempo. El tiempo es lo que la atmósfera hace en el corto plazo, hora a hora, día a día. El tiempo es caótico, lo que significa que incluso una alteración microscópica puede provocar cambios a gran escala. Eso es por lo que esas predicciones del tiempo a diez días no valen para nada. Una mariposa agita sus alas en Bali y seis semanas después el tiempo arruina tu boda en Maine. 

El clima es la media del tiempo a largo plazo después de muchos años. Está moldeado por fuerzas globales que alteran el equilibrio de energía en la atmósfera. Tales como cambios en el sol, o movimientos del eje terrestre, la cantidad de luz que la Tierra refleja hacia el espacio o la concentración de gases de efecto invernadero en el aire. Un cambio en cualquiera de ellas afecta al clima de una manera que es probablemente predecible. Mi amigo serpenteando representa las fluctuaciones más cortas, eso es el tiempo. Es casi imposible dónde predecir cuál será el olor que le interese a continuación, pero no es difícil saber en qué rango se moverá este serpenteo, porque lo estoy sujetando con una correa. No podemos observar el clima directamente, siempre lo vemos como el tiempo, el tiempo medio durante el curso de los años reconstruye un patrón. Yo represento esa tendencia a largo plazo, que es el clima. Pon tu ojo en el hombre, no en el perro. 

El tiempo es difícil de predecir, como mi amigo aquí, pero el clima es previsible. El clima ha cambiado muchas veces en la larga historia de la Tierra pero siempre respondía a alguna fuerza global. La mayor fuerza que dirige el cambio climático ahora mismo es el incremento del CO2 procedente de la quema de combustibles fósiles, que está atrapando más calor del sol. Toda esa energía adicional tiene que ir a alguna parte. Parte calienta la Tierra y la mayoría termina en los mares. Por todo el planeta los océanos se están calentando".

author: Megan Maines

text:
@Megan Maines 
 "how large these effects of green house gasses are in comparison to the natural fluctuation of the earth's climate"

http://www.realclimate.org/images/ipcc_rad_forc_ar5.jpg

here you see those forcings. the forcings we create, cooling and warming , dominate all others currently. but surely nature is able to cause much bigger focings. but is currently not. and usualy take much longer, like orbital forcings together with the feedbacks that caused glacial periods. or if they are fast like cooling from volcanic erruptions, they only last a few years.
our CO2 stays a long time in the atmosphere and accumulates, and over that time it absorbs and reradiates IR radiation. which causes a pretty big forcing on the climate system.

" It seems to me that the amount of thermal energy obtained from the sun alone would dwarf the amount of thermal energy that becomes trapped by these gasses.  "

that is actually true. the sun deliver virtually all thermal energy (0.4% comes from our planet's core) on our planet. but normaly when the climate is near equilibrium, all that energy is radiated off into space by IR radiation. but when you increase the GHG concentration. we move away from equilibrium and heat accumulates. that means, the planet cannot radiate off the energy into space as efficiently as before the increase in GHG.
but the additional amount is dwarfed when you compare it to the total energy we receive.
1.68 W/m² from CO2 compared to ca. 1360 W/m² on top of the atmosphere of which some 240 W/m² is absorbed by the surface and atmosphere.

but you can compare that to a tank with 100 liter / minute inlet and 100 liter / minute outlet. its in equilibrium, but when you reduce the outlet to 99 litre / minute you accumulate 1 liter / minute. while the 100 input still dwarfes the 1 litre accumulation, it still leads to an accumulation and the tank will fill up. and that is the problem. we heat up slowly. but as we still increase the CO2 concentration, the planet does not come close to equilibrium. means it will continue to warm up slowly. if we stopped increasing CO2 concentration today, it would still take a long time until we reach near equilibrium and stop warming up.

here a blog by climatologist where they explain such things very well.

http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2010/03/climate-change-commitments/

what is more interesting than comparing total incoming thermal energy from the sun to how much CO2 accumulates thermal energy. is how the solar output changes.
and this is very slightly towards cooling. since the 1960 the solar cycles have become a bit weaker. that is why climatologist and solar experts conclude that the sun cannot explain the late 20th century warming. in the early 20th century that was different. then the solar activity increased significantly. that is why climatologist attribute the early 20th century warming mainly to the sun and only a little to anthropogenic causes.

and here lies the key, we know that nature can cause much larger changes than we are causing currently (mostly not so fast, but still) that is why we need to figure out the different forcings. like how much changes solar output, or the orbital forcings from the milankovitch cycles (also towards cooling since 2 millenia and expected to continue for several 10 000's of years. naturally we should be slowly cooling into the next glacial period) or volcanic activity etc etc.

text:
Earths Atmospheric gas concentration: Nitrogen 78%, Oxygen 21%, CO2 0.03% and the other gasses( Argon, water vapor etc.) make up the other 0.97%.  It is strange that such a small percentage of gas has such a profound effect on a planet.
Now CO2 is constantly recycled.  If you think of it the CO2 released through the burning of fossil fuels is actually the energy stored by plants millions of years ago, hence the term "fossil fuels".  So you see this CO2 existed long before man was around.
Every day CO2 is absorbed by plants to grow.  Plants use sunlight to "fix" carbon atoms into complex polysaccharide chains to grow and in the process release oxygen. Literal tons of CO2 are absorbed in this process. All the food we eat started off as a plant somewhere. We consume tons of plant matter every year as food. With the ever expanding population we need to increase food production.  Now increase concentration of CO2 helps plants grow. http://www.news.illinois.edu/news/09/0209co2.html
So maybe we need the increase in CO2 to feed the increasing population?
It is funny how all the politicians who squawk about climate change the only policy changes they want to make are to increase taxes and fees and to pass more regulations which mostly only affect the middle class.  Seems to me like it is a power grab.  Instead of taxes and regulations how about addressing deforestation and urban growth.  Just saying.

author: Yvigny Goncharov

text:
I have some time to kill, so I am going to tell you why you are completely wrong.

1.  There are very few, if any, scientists making six figure speaking salaries.  Research scientists (you know, the ones actually writing the peer-reviewed papers) make significantly less than scientists working in the private sector.  Even if you could name 5 climate scientists making six figure salaries speaking it wouldn't mean beans to the state of climate science.  AGW's validity doesn't rest on 5 or even 10 individuals.  There are hundreds researching climate change and the over-whelming majority accept AGW.

2.  Tyson wouldn't show the raw data because it would be a long, boring show.  If you honestly want the data, the peer-reviewed papers are available.  You could start at realclimate.org, which is authored by authentic climate scientists and has numerous citations to real research papers.  You could probably spend a month just reading that site.  Tyson did a great job summing up the truth and in an entertaining way.

3.  You make the claim that AGW is disproved by an offhand prediction of a weather event.  This just illustrates your ignorance of the subject.  Climate is not weather.  Weather is chaotic, climate is not.  Which is why climate is much easier to predict than weather.  Climate trends are determined over long time periods.  Which is one of the reasons the often mentioned by climate deniers "17-year pause" is not a problem for AGW theory.  Regardless, scientists are often quoted by the media making off-hand predictions.  These aren't scientific predictions and one person saying such does not invalidate the 1000's of papers supporting the reality of AGW.

4.  The only people who think AGW is a joke, are the deniers.  Of those deniers, less than 1% are actually climate scientists.  That says a lot about deniers.  So keep yucking it up if you want to look like a fool.  I have no idea what deniers motivation is.  Politics?  Don't like the solution?  There are free market solutions...

To address another one of your comments - there is ABSOLUTELY consensus in science.  For example, you will be hard pressed to find any scientist who disagrees with germ theory.  So there is a consensus that germ theory is correct.
author: Eric Arlington

text:
@Yvigny Goncharov 

This would be a good time to mention that I am a scientist (as in, y'know, I get paid to do research). Now, I am not a Climate Scientist and I'm extremely early in my career, but you know what I do know? Statistical mechanics and thermodynamics.

Ultimately, the climate is a thermodynamic system. The beautiful thing about thermodynamics is that it lets you make extremely powerful predictions without knowing the specifics of the underlying system - which is the world of statistical mechanics.

I'm going to draw another analogy; look at say, your desk or some seemingly inert object near you. That object has some temperature, right? Some very stable temperature. But guess what? That given temperature state is made up of a truly huge number of what we call microstates - and we're talking easily on the order of googolplexes here, if not larger.

The weather is those microstates, and the climate is the inert object with some stable temperature. You're missing the forest for the trees, my friend.

As for the consensus point; I have bad news for you - not everybody's opinion is worth the same. If a doctor tells me that I have heart disease, and a chiropractor tells me that I don't, who do you think I'm going to listen to?

In this case, there are thousands of (climate) scientists who have examined the facts and found that they support AGW. There are a few scientists who do not, but they are absolutely in the minority. Does that mean that they are wrong? Not necessarily, but it does mean they are much more likely to be wrong. Everybody else who is denying climate change is not a climate scientist, and so their opinion on the matter is negligible.

Anything else I'd want to address has been done so by Eric Arlington.
author: Daniel Blay
Yvigny Goncharov

text:
@Daniel Blay  In this case, there are thousands of (climate) scientists who have examined the facts and found that they support AGW. 

And there are TENS of thousands of SCIENTISTS who challenge the very PROCESSES used to produce that support. You don't need to be a climate scientist to recognize BAD SCIENCE.

}}}  There are a few scientists who do not, but they are absolutely in the minority. 

Over THIRTY THOUSAND scientists signed ONE PETITION stating that they were clearly unhappy with the METHODOLOGY being used to support the AGW Hypothesis. Gosh, that's nothing!!  That's not a hell of a lot of PROFESSIONAL who didn't like what they were hearing. But hey, they aren't "Climate Scientists", so clearly they could not know ANYTHING of value. 

No, only a High Priest of Climate Science is allowed to read the tea leaves and feel the phrenologies to properly interpret their science!!

Have you heard of "The Decline Effect"? No? So much for your knowledge of science. Seems that lots and lots of "peer reviewed" studies of 15 and 20 years ago are being set up again in an effort to replicate them... and they're failing replication. Why? Various reasons, of course -- but the most common is SLOPPY METHODOLOGY.  You know, the exact same kind of thing that that petition was concerned with.

...Also problematic:  an over-reliance on "peer review" instead of actual experimental reproduction of results, which is, rather than "consensus", the true GOLD standard of all REAL science.

"Give me your data and instructions on how you produced your results, so I can try and get similar results myself"

THAT is science. And if you're half the expert you claim, you'd know this.

But what of AGW? No, that's not how "Climate Scientists" work, not at all. They refuse to release data and methodology. They will only "give" their results to others with like mind, who, gosh, find the same results!!! Whodathunkit? I asked a thousand Democrats if Obama was doing a great job!! And what do you know, 990 of them thought so!! Clearly, IT MUST BE TRUE!!

The major climate "think tanks" have even gone so far as to destroy raw data to prevent anyone from working up their own variations, to see if it fits -- PREDICTS -- things better. Whole terabytes of raw historical numbers have just *conveniently* "disappeared and become unavailable. But hey, we've got these MASSAGED numbers we used that you can use, too!!

What is "consensus" worth? Jack and his smelly companion, that's what.

In 1885, EVERY knowledgeable scientist of EVERY stripe knew exactly how light propagated about the universe. Then TWO GUYS, Michaelson and Morely, did an experiment. As knowledge of those results became widespread, as others replicated their simple experiment (even you could conduct this experiment, probably in your garage), by 1890, EVERYONE knew that they had no freaking CLUE how light propagated. 

In 1912, a well-known meteorologist and polar researcher -- note, he was not a geologist -- advanced the notion that continents MOVED. The "consensus" was SURE he was crazy to believe it. And yet.... forty years passed, and something very strange happened -- evidence began to roll in to support that notion. And now it is accepted that, in fact, continents move. One guy, vs. a consensus. Who was right? 

And those two examples are hardly the only ones -- there is an array of ideas which struggled to find acceptance in the face of "consensus". And anyone who claims -- or attempts to claim -- that the consensus MUST be right, BECAUSE it is the consensus, is NOT a scientist, no matter what they earn their salary doing.
author: Yvigny Goncharov

text:
@Yvigny Goncharov 

Seriously, dude? Why does EVERY second WORD have to be in ALL CAPS? 

Let's get one thing clear, right off the bat - that 'petition'? Most of the people who 'signed' it had no idea what they were signing. This is well known, and that point has been refuted a thousand times. Let's make that an acronym. P.R.A.T. - Point Refuted A Thousand Times.

Secondly, yes, I'm well aware that there is a lot of science that's come out as bogus - and you know what? It's limited to very particular fields, the worst offender being medical science, not climate science.

Thirdly, peer review is not intended as a replacement for replication. However, replication can take a very long time. If you are half the expert you claim to be, you would know this. You also provide no sources for this so called failed replication. The data and methodologies are also readily available, so I have no idea what you're talking about on that point.

Fourthly, 'dogma' in science - P.R.A.T.

Fifthly - why would '30 years of experience with computers' have any bearing on this? Furthermore, your 'half a physics degree' doesn't mean much. I have an entire physics degree, and I don't think that makes me a qualified climate scientist.

Ultimately your points all boil down to 'there's a global scientist conspiracy for which I have no proof'.

Finally, your historical examples are true - those things did happen. But, for one, I never claimed that we could not be wrong, I talked about possibilities, for precisely this reason. It may be that somebody will perform the experiment to show that AGW is not real - but guess what? It hasn't happened yet. No single reputable source has done it, and 'reputable' does matter.
This argument also ignores all of the other cases where the person in the minority was wrong, which, you guessed it, is what happens the vast majority of the time.

text:
Johnny, Johnny, Johnny, Your question is total horse-shit and you know it. Let me explain and I won't use big words so you'll be able to understand.

CO2 is a greenhouse gas, that's a fact. Burning Fossil Fuels (Oil, Coal, Natural Gas, ect) releases the CO2 that's trapped in them, Millions of tons per year in fact; FAAAAAAR more than plants and the ocean can absorb. That CO2 that isn't absorbed, stays in the atmosphere, it doesn't just magically go away. If you don't believe me, look at Venus. Lead is a liquid on that planet. Now over years, more and more CO2 stays in the atmosphere and traps the heat from sunlight, that too is a fact. I hope you're still with me, because this is where things get bad. When the atmosphere gets warmer, that causes the oceans to get warmer and polar ice caps to melt, also a fact, it's happening. Fresh water causes salinity in oceans to decrease, that's bad. As salinity decreases, that disrupts ocean currents, very bad. That means that heat and cold are no longer evenly distributed across the planet. The UK which receives heat from the equator on  the North Atlantic Drift now, all of a sudden, doesn't. That causes temperatures in the UK that were pleasant, to now be well below zero, and since the equator can't distribute it's heat to the north, that causes the equator to go from 80 to 150 degrees. I hope you're still with me, because I'm almost done. Now last time I checked, people can't live in a place that's below zero or in 150. That's climate change and that's happening now. I hope I answered your horse-shit question.

text:
If you've made your mind up, you are not a skeptic.

It's clear you are not a skeptic, nor do you understand science. There is no "correct temperature". There is a range that sustains life. Our sun typically warms our planet to about 53º F. The greenhouse gasses further increase this temperature to a level that sustains life. The difficulty is, we are increasing the number of greenhouse gasses, which is increasing the temperature beyond sustainable levels.

If you're really interested (i.e. a skeptic, and interested in learning facts) go and look it up. If you're more interested in repeating what Rush Limbaugh or Fox "News" (or any of the Ayn Rand idiots) tell you to believe, at least look up the word skeptic, and learn that doesn't describe you.

You're either part of the solution, or part of the problem. Please put down your political prejudices, grow up, and build a better future for your children.
author: Neil G

text:
@John Galt 
 John! Just because you don't understand something, does not make it "Not True". There is no one single temperature that is ideal for for the entire planet. That is why your question is total horse-shit and you know it! The temperature ranges are different all over the planet. The fact of the matter is, those temperatures are rising all over the planet equally at the same rate. We know for a fact (due to ice core samples) that there is more CO2 in the atmosphere now than 300 years ago. What started happening 300 years ago? Hmmmm, oh yeah, we started burning coal. Also, your little CO2 rant is flat out wrong. I don't know where you got your "facts" but I'm thinking you pulled them out of your ass. Here is a real fact, we are putting 2.4 million pounds of CO2 into the atmosphere per second. Not day, not month, not year, per second! And as I said, the CO2 that isn't absorbed by plants and the ocean doesn't just go away, it continues to build up. If the CO2 in our atmosphere increased to just 6 molecules out of 10,000, the entire Earth would be a barren wasteland desert.

You have already made up your mind and it's completely closed to anything anyone will say that will contradict what you already think. That is also why your question is total horse-shit; you are not open to think otherwise. Climate Change is happening, that is a FACT whether you believe it or not.

BTW, Water Vapor is NOT a green house gas you dumbass, which is why I didn't bring it up. More water vapor would, in fact, cool the planet by creating clouds. Those clouds would then reflect sunlight back into space. If you even had the slightest idea what you were attempting to talk about, you would've known that. To quote you, "Nice try".
author: Holly McCann

text: @John Galt  It's interesting to see terms as "Green Priests" and "believe" trying to be applied on a scientific topic. For a moment I thought your question was serious. My bad. In any case and always in the hope of enlightening whoever is curious, this publication "Changes in atmospheric constituents and in radiative forcing" by Uni Cambridge in 2007 is quite explanatory of the topic you seem to address. (If I get your idea right, you postulate that anthropogenic influence in climate is negligible) I can give you a quote from the abstract: "The combined anthropogenic RF is estimated to be +1.6 [–1.0, +0.8] W m^(–2), indicating that, since 1750, it is extremely likely that humans have exerted a substantial warming influence on climate. This RF estimate is likely to be at least five times greater than that due to solar irradiance changes." Just as a parallel example to give you language clarity: another "Extremely likely" theory in current use by mankind is gravity. Here the complete chapter in PDF format: http://www.ipcc.ch/pdf/assessment-report/ar4/wg1/ar4-wg1-chapter2.pdf

text:
The polar jetstreams are caused by temperature differences between the poles and the equator. The ice at the poles melts and so the resulting water absorbs more insolation because the liquid form is darker than solid ice. Thus, the poles warm up twice as fast as the rest of the Earth, resulting in weaker jetstreams. With less momemtum, as a fluid, the air of the jetstream is more likely to meander. When that happens you get Rossby waves as the polar front undulates, forming a miniature cyclone. Geography must be very hard for Americans.

I also find it quite funny that you can't use proper grammar, especially capitalisation and proper apostrophe use. It's also hilarious that elitism is demonised by you. So long meritocracy, hello groupthink and demagoguery?

Anyway, I guess that I will have to dumb down my position, so that you can follow along.  Ready?  OK, here it goes...  I neither believe nor disbelieve that man made global warming is happening.  I do believe that scientists on one end of the spectrum theorize that we are to blame, and scientists on the other end that we may be contributing to global warming but not to the point of damaging the earth.  Somehow, all of these scientists got lumped into a "97% are in agreement" pot, but hey, what the hell.  In short, they all guess that we may be doing it, to one extent or another.  You know, kinda like the big bang.  There was nothing, then a bang, and now there is everything.  We guess that was the start, but who knows for sure.  Plenty of evidence to support it, but then there is plenty of evidence to support intelligent design too.  It all really comes down to where you put your faith.  On a side note, don't you think its interesting that scientists expect people to believe that everything came from nothing, but then act like intelligent design is ridiculous?  Anyway, my point is that when dealing with the unknowable its always just a guess.  Maybe an educated guess, but still a guess.

So, that being said, I found myself in a place of not really knowing what is fact.  At that point I looked closely at both sides of the argument to see what the possible solutions being pushed are.  You know what I found?  I found that, in a nutshell, most governments are pushing to enact legislation that will take freedoms and money from many individuals and private businesses.  I also found that there are many people and companies, mostly of the socialist/communist persuasion, that stand to make billions if these legislations are passed.  Oh sure, there are the big oil guys in there trying to keep their interests alive.  However these forces are a drop in the bucket compared the state sponsored climate change side.  I have to laugh when you think some oil company, not matter how rich, has a chance against governments who can literally print money.  Im actually impressed that the oil guys have managed to make an impression at all, truth be told.  And hey, people like you are living proof that the governments have done their job well.  I do believe that you would fight for this to your last breath, and still refuse to have an original thought on the subject.

I think that most people passionate about this issue are focused on the wrong thing.

So, I will ask you again:  Is there a way to deal with this issue that does not infringe on our prosperity and freedoms?  At the end of the day, that is really all I care about.  Not some petty fight about who is right or wrong.
author: jjallison1

text:
@***** 
On August 17, 2014 the Arctic sea ice extent was 1.03 million square kilometers (398,000 square miles) below the 1981 to 2010 long-term average. That's nearly two standard deviations below the average. Do you know anything about statistics? That's a lot. You do know what happened the last time deniers crowed about two years of 'recovery' in the ice cap size? The following year it fell to the record lowest extent ever since it started to be measured. As I said about rising temperatures (and it also applies to rising heat stored in the oceans and the rising sea levels), it's never a smooth line. But here's a tip, go to the scientists for science. Don't swallow the slurry that a right-wing British rag – with a long track record of lying (and support for Adolf Hitler, incidentally) – pours down your throat. Here's a good site – nsidc [dot]org/arcticseaicenews/charctic-interactive-sea-ice-graph/ You'll see the far more relevant fact that when satellite records began in 1979, on this day in that year the Arctic ice cap was 1.763 million sq kilometres bigger than it is now. Do also read that whole article which gets a lot less gung-ho when they start quoting the scientists – "‘I’m uncomfortable with the idea of people saying the ice has bounced back." Dr Ed Hawkins, Reading University. Finally, you do know what a prediction is? That's when people say something like, "the Arctic will be ice-free in 2014". Al Gore said it "could" be. That's not really a prediction. Finally, finally, can you please stop putting apostrophes in your plurals. It makes you look even more ill-informed and under-educated than the actual content of your posts does.

We should reduce emissions and pollution regardless but more importantly not take information for face value and dig in every direction. The best conclusion i have come to seems that we're on a cooling trend headed toward a cycle in the sun called a grand solar minimum. A period of decrease in solar activity which then in turn shifts the climate into an ice age. This is why unfortunately they had to go from climate warming to climate change. It didn't fit because the ipcc's  models did not include enough variables. When it was founded the sun was excluded for cause because they were only focusing on anthropogenic climate causes. The point is science is as corrupt as our politics and now they are hand and hand. At this point it's not a matter of cause, it's a matter of what people need to prepare for if this shifting pattern continues, anthropogenic or not.

text:
Actually you are right there John overall the sea ice in the 'Antarctic' is growing.

Quotes from Coby Beck:  "Around the peninsula, where there is a lot of warming, the ice is retreating. This is the area of the recent and dramatic Larsen B and Ross ice shelf breakups."

"But the rest of the continent has not shown any clear warming or cooling and sea ice has increased over the last decade or so."

"This is not actually a big surprise."

"In fact, it is completely in line with model expectations that CO2-dominated forcing will have a disproportionately large effect in the north. The reasons lie in the much larger amount of land in the northern hemisphere and the fact that the ocean’s thermal inertia and ability to mix delay any temperature signal from the ongoing absorption of heat. The local geography also plays a dominating role. The circumpolar current acts as a buffer preventing warm water from the tropics from transporting heat to the South Pole, a buffer that does not exist in the north." 

"Does it “balance out” in the end? Not really. Sea ice in the Arctic is reaching dramatic record lows. There are other components of the cryosphere that we can look at as well, permafrost, the Greenland ice sheet, global glacier mass, and these all carry the Global Warming signal."

"One must look at the balance of evidence, not just those bits one likes. And this balance is clearly in agreement with all other indicators that warming is real and rapid."

text:
The first five months of 2014 have been the coldest since the National Weather Service began keeping records in 1888. If “climate change” alarmists got out more, they might have noticed.
Between 1979 — when weather satellites started measuring temperatures in the lower troposphere — and 1997, they rose about 1.1 degrees Celsius (1.98 degrees Fahrenheit).
Temperatures stopped rising then, have fallen since 2012. The “pause” in warming (212 months) is now longer than the warming trend was (211 months).
The earth has warmed about 16 degrees F since the last ice age. The net increase since 1979 — 0.19 degrees C (0.34 F) — is well within the range of natural fluctuation.
So why, as President Barack Obama says so often, do 97 percent of scientists agree climate change is “real, man-made, and dangerous?”
They don’t. This bogus stat is derived from two questions University of Illinois researchers asked in a survey of earth scientists in 2008:
1. “When compared with pre-1800s levels, do you think that mean global temperatures have generally risen, fallen, or remained relatively constant?”
2. “Do you think human activity is a significant contributing factor in changing mean global temperatures?”
The researchers culled from 3,146 responses those of 79 climate scientists who’d been published in peer reviewed journals. Seventy-six answered “risen” to the first question; 75 “yes” to the second.
Temperatures have risen since the Little Ice Age ended around 1870, skeptics agree. Most think the activities of humans have some effect on them.
The key question is whether that effect is big enough to do harm, but that’s not what the scientists were asked.
John Cook, climate communication fellow (a publicist, not a climate scientist) at the University of Queensland in Australia and eight colleagues examined abstracts of 11,944 articles on climate published between 1991 and 2011.
“Among abstracts expressing a position . . . 97.1 percent endorsed the consensus position that humans are causing global warming,” they concluded in a paper last May.
Which is as meaningless as the “consensus” in the two-question survey, for the same reason.
Skeptics agree humans cause some warming. Mr. Cook et. al. included papers by prominent skeptics Willie Soon, Craig Idso, Nocola Scafetta, Nir Shaviv, Nils-Axel Morner and Alan Carlin in their 97.1 percent “consensus.”
Only 41 papers (0.3 percent) explicitly state support for Mr. Cook’s assertion that humans have caused most of the warming since 1950, former Delaware state climatologist David Legates and three colleagues found in a peer reviewed study last September.
“It is astonishing that any journal could have published a paper claiming a 9 percent climate consensus when on the authors’ own analysis the true consensus was well below 1 percent,” Mr. Legates said.
Carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has increased from about 285 parts per million 250 years ago to about 380 ppm today. CO2 is a “greenhouse” gas -- it holds heat in the atmosphere -- so if humans are generating more, it should have a warming effect.
But probably not much of one. Greenhouse gases comprise less than 1 percent of the earth’s atmosphere; carbon dioxide is less than 4 percent of greenhouse gases; 96 percent of CO2 in the atmosphere was put there by Mother Nature.
Compared to variations in solar radiation and other natural forces, the effect of greenhouse gases on climate is trivial.
“There is no convincing scientific evidence that human release of carbon dioxide, methane, or other greenhouse gases is causing or will, in the foreseeable future, cause catastrophic heating of the Earth’s atmosphere and disruption of the Earth’s climate,” says a petition signed by more than 31,000 American scientists in climate-related disciplines.
That’s rather more than 79 or 41. There is no scientific consensus on human-caused global warming, and there shouldn’t be.
“If it’s science, it isn’t consensus,” said Mr. Soon, a solar expert at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics. “If it’s consensus, it isn’t science.”
Scientists search for truth by observation and experimentation, not by taking polls. Consensus is a political concept.
The skeptics are true to the scientific method. The abusers of science are those who politicize it.

Weather events like fires and tornadoes cost millions of dollars to clean up, not to mention the loss of life. Many medicines are found in the rain forests, but if we allow them to be cut down for profit or destroyed due to climate change, we will never discover them. Increasing temperatures create a breeding ground for infectious bacteria, viruses, and fungi. If humans die off because of our own short-term thinking, there will be no jobs or money. 

Humans depend on nature to live (i.e. growing food, breathing clean air, drinking water) and make money. It is nice to think about climate as this thing that happens outside of humans and that we can sit in our nice, air conditioned houses while "lesser" beings die, but human health and livelihood is entirely reliant on the environment.

text:
Can't predict weather. Can predict climate. You didn't understand the clip.

The range in which weather can vary is determined by the amount of heat in the fluid surface of the planet - the ocean and air. Heat can only get into or leave that 'envelope' via radiation to/from space. There are only a few major mechanisms that influence this radiation - the sun's output, how much is reflected vs. absorbed, and how much gets out according to the chemistry effects in the atmosphere, the "greenhouse effect". When more heat is coming in than going out, it is not hard to predict warming. While there are complex factors underneath these top-level ones (e.g., temperature can influence cloud formation, which can influence reflectivity or the level at which heat rises before emitting into space and many other complex factors) but it is still possible for science to categorize and rank the influence of different factors.

Try another analogy. You put a pot of water on to boil. Scientists point to the flame on and say "the water will bubble and vanish". Critics say 'well, if you have these amazing prediction powers, tell me precisely where and when each and every bubble will appear in the water.' Scientists say 'well that's chaotic, we can tell you a range for that but not exactly.' Critics say 'see! they admit they can't even predict the bubbles! There is no reason to believe they know the water will boil at all.'

You should watch the whole episode, and genuinely try to learn.

text:
Solar activity has been flat or declining since the 1950s, yet global temperature spiked up.

Think about a heated room with insulation. How warm the room will be after a short period of heat depends on both the amount of heat coming in and the amount of heat getting out. Otherwise, there would be no reason to put insulation in your home. The main factor which controls how much heat leaves the earth is the greenhouse effect. Without it, the earth would be a snowball, and there would be no life as we know it.

It is an interesting (and important) subject, I encourage you to read more – not just political sites, but you should direcxtly read what the scientists have to say as well.

text:
"Changes in the Sun, tilt of the Earth's axis, amount of sunlight the Earth reflects back into space, and greenhouse gases."

There are a lot of variables going on in those global forces. We also underestimate the power of the Sun, a minor change in its atmospheric processes and the Earth experiences drastic effects in radiation and temperature. In addition, with the added warmth currently being proposed on the atmosphere, there should be more extreme weather but that is not occurring. Meteorological history proves that events which we have witnessed this decade have indeed happened decades and even centuries ago. Water vapor is the domineering greenhouse gas, as it encompasses most of the atmospheric composition and has a higher heat capacity than carbon dioxide. So, as of now, we have yet to observe drastic increases in MSL heights and have yet to observe continuous catastrophic meteorological events. So even if the Earth is warming slightly, the effects are not observable. Also, the USA has a significantly higher amount of automated surface observing stations (ASOS) than any other country in the world, so we get a greater density of data than any other place. There are a myriad of factors involved here, it is impossible to narrow it down to just one mere factor.

text:
As much as I respect Neil, on this issue he is incorrect.  The "butterfly effect" is a metaphor taken out of context to explain the chaos theory.  It is not testable, provable, or falsifiable.  Climate is dictated by weather, and the two are inseparable, and semantics won't help the discussion.  Aside from the fact that for nearly 18 years the global average temperature has been falling.
What is happening is normal climate variability.  To state otherwise is to assume the idea that climatic conditions must remain the same over time, and that's not an option.  Like the stock market, it will go up and it will go down.  That's what we know.  Oh, and we're still coming out of the Little Ice Age too.

Did he mention the distance of the moon in relation to the earth. The moons orbit acts as sort of a damper to the Earths movement and as the moon moves farther away from the Earth the Earth wobbles just a little more on its axis which changes the trajectory of the Sun's rays in relation with the equator which has been the fundamental reason for global climate change long before man ever inhabitted the Earth or burned fossil fuels.
About 25% of the Earth is land and less than 7% of that 25% is actually inhabitted by people and not all of these people burn fossil fuels. So saying the burning of fossil fuels is the most significant reason for climate change seems a little far fetched.
Curiously the same folks trying convince us that all this man made CO causing the "greenhouse" effect can be balanced by adjusting our exhaust emissions from machinery into nothing more than water vapor. This seems suspicious because it doesn't take a scientist to be aware of the fact  that water in the form of vapor has the most significant green house effect of all other known gases. Any one suffering from sunburn or heat exhaustion on a hazy day could figure that out.

text:
@*****  I've read it, it took me a while though.
I understood, from my reading, something totally different from what you did. However I want to know what do you do for a living. That might be the difference in our focus.

As an engineer and a laboratory scientist, It is clear to me, the last 2 documents present a plan to reduce the human impact on the environment. The plan focus on management of resources, handling contamination and reducing population. Neither document makes affirmations about poisoning people or exterminating large amounts of them. Neither is there a free card to polute as much as any country wants. What it says is that the amount of pollution and greenhouse gases (unavoidable right now) permited to developed countries has a limit. This limit is permited because other countries dont pollute as much and is a grace amount for them to start making changes to achieve a total reduction of 80% in emitions for 2050.
 
About reducing population: It's only logical that with less people in the world there will be less environmental impact. Then it is needed a policy to reduce the amount of people in the world. The fastest growth of population happens in the poorest section.
Let me remind you that the people who run the world (unfortunately) is the mere 1%. The rest of us are in the 99%, that's the part that need to be slowly reduce through the next 3 decades. The means to do that need off course be humanitarian and respectful.
No matter how much we try it, they can't be touched unless you become one of them.

As Holdren does, I also believe we need to force people to be birth responsible, no other species in the planet has more children than the ones than can be fed, except , the viruses.
I understand if you feel insulted , but this is not a plot, it is widely open, there's not rich people trying to kill poor ones. There's simply poor people growing in alarming numbers. The rich ones can only sit there and wait for us to suffocate each other over the water, the food and the air, They can pay for it the 1% has 90% of the money and resources. This plan is for me a better deal, to slowly decrease and control the number of births will save us.

There shouldn't exist couples with more than 2 children. In the cave ages it was logical to have many kids because the wild life was dangerous, the medicine wasnt advanced enough and the flu could kill you. So a few survived. in modern times we have so much technological advances that there's no need to have >2 children, to do so is not only irresponsible but an attack against human species.

text:
@*****  it took me a while to respond, I was in an actual science laboratory doing research. Not the kind for global warming though, but more like Thermodinamics and materials science. I mention this because I want you to understand that reading ot writing about science, and actually understanding it are 2 different things. 

What you present as flaws in the tests (like the Antartic ice for the Carbon measures) are really opinions, because it is a fact that those tests work. And the anomalies you mention don't affect the result not by even 1%. A fact is no subjest to debate or opinion. You can't deny gravity.

Just to be clear we (The Scientific Community) are not saying in the past there hasn't been any global warming and subsequent cooling, because there has been, We are alarmed because the rate at with the temperature is rising is being accelerated by human actions over the natural limit.

With all the respect let me tell you, as an Engineer and an artist (I also write comics about science fiction) I understand your drive to go against the system, but you are just doing it for the sake of being against something. Science fiction and Science ARE NOT, I'll repeat ARE NOT parts of the same coin. The fact that Pickard used tablets 20 years ago or that Jules Verne wrote about sending a man to the moon only proves the inspirational nature of art.

To be an artist it is enough with being talented and there's not really a need to study and learn about technical and theoretical stuff. Some of the best writers have made huge science mistakes and they've never been accountable for it. To be a scientific you need to understand physics, chemistry, mathematics, materials, medicine and others. And people lifes and technology advancements depend on your calculations and decisions, we are always accountable for that.

So don't mix oranges with apples. artists are as needed as Scientists but not in the same coin, more like in a nthaedron with our faces being the ones fartest from each other.

text:
@*****  I'll try to make my explanation brief:

1- Nature is huge and scientists study it and develop technology to use it to our advance. If you need proof just look at your phone, at your medicines, at the electricity in your home. Nature has multiple branches, so there's the need for different type of scientists to study all of it (astrophysics, thermodynamics, quantum mechanics, geology, etc).
2- But all the different scientists share a foundation in knowledge of physics, chemistry, Biology, to name a few. And more importantly all of them use the same method, the Scientific Method. This method is flawless, because the method itself asks you to keep trying to debunk what's already accepted if new evidence appears. If the mayority of scientists of a certain branch have tried this method and adquired the same results in light of different experiments and conditions, who are we to call them liars? Unless you are a speciallist on Weather you'll be relying on other people who are. And 97% of those people concluded that the earth is getting warmer because of us.

3- As you pointed,Mr Tyson doesn't proves anything on his show, to prove something you must run tests and trials in a laboratory or in the site where the phenomenom takes place. 97% of the weather scientists around the globe already did this and found the same results which give 97% of the sureness they are right. Because the rest of the scientific community shares the basic knowledge, but is already working on something else, we cannot run the same tests, but we can review and evaluate the material presented. That's how you get a second layer of confidence on the matter. 

4- We, the scientists never give a truth for granted, everything is subject to test and trial. That's why science teachers take you to laboratories to duplicate the experiments instead of making you read about them, to make you see with your eyes if possible.
This show aims to encourage the new generations to do science. To interest them in its study, to be knowledgeable, to design experiments and find evidence to support or refute what we know.

That's why my friend your position is not only a product of paranoia and a cry to find exciting ideas to write and read, it is insulting to the people who made possible that you could be reading this. This document which I wrote miles away from you, that you can read seconds after I finish it with a wireless connection inside an apartment with lights at night inside a building of 20 stories high, after not dying from the common flu and being totally calm when seeing a comet knowing that it is not a premonition that God is going to punish us.

You are welcome, from the Scientists before me who made all this possible and let us walk on their shoulders and their vision.

text:
@reed tomlinson  at·mos·phere: the envelope of GASES surrounding the earth or another planet.

The molecules of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse (green·house ef·fect: noun- the trapping of the sun's warmth in a planet's lower atmosphere due to the greater transparency of the atmosphere to visible radiation from the sun than to infrared radiation emitted from the planet's surface.)   gases effectively form a blanket around Earth - more heat enters than is able to escape.  (this is that insulation thing you can't seem to grasp)  you douche bag idiot moron

The heat we receive from the sun (solar radiation) has a very short wavelength and is able to pass through the atmosphere unimpeded. (the sun is that big yellow thing in the sky during the day) you twit

The sun heats the ground, oceans and everything on the planet's surface and this heat is radiated back into the atmosphere as thermal radiation. This has a longer wavelength than solar radiation and some of the heat energy is unable to escape through the blanket of greenhouse gases. (basic science principles that can be told to you by children) you twat

There is more or less a natural equilibrium but in the last 250 years the levels of greenhouse gases have been increasing through the burning of fossil fuels, agricultural activities, deforestation etc. The result has been an increase in atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations - effectively a thickening of the blanket. 

By analyzing ice core samples stretching back over the last 650,000 years we know that natural levels of CO2 vary between 190 and 310 parts per million by volume. In recent years levels have risen to 385 ppmv and are still rising. 

So, in a nutshell, solar radiation enters the atmosphere and thermal radiation is prevented from escaping, the more greenhouse gases there are the less thermal radiation escapes.

text:
To those among us that think the burning of fossil fuels isn't causing climate change, try this little experiment... Find yourself a nice little warehouse building with a concrete floor. And bring along a nice comfy chair as well as a half cord of wood or maybe a quarter barrel of fuel oil.  Now shut the door behind you, light whatever fuel source you brought with you and have a seat. Of course you're not going to survive to give us the results of your experiment. But when they finally find your body sometime later in a structure that has finally cooled due to radiant and conductive cooling, they'll determine that you died from carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide poisoning and or oxygen deprivation. Not to mention possibly showing signs of heat stroke. Leaving only your corpse in a chair and the remainder of whatever fuel source to you choose that couldn't combust do to lack of oxygen. As well as a nice layer off soot (basically carbon) covering everything- including your dead body.
The lesson: The earth earth and its atmosphere are no different. Only it will take longer for the earth to cool back down due to the lack heat conduction.

text:
Thank You Neil deGrasse Tyson! 
I love this Cosmos series, and listening to one America's most brilliant Scientific minds. 
"...Climate is predictable. Climate has changed many times  throughout the history of the earth, but always in response to a global force. The strongest force driving climate change right now is the increasing Co2 from the burning of fossil fuels, which is trapping more heat from the sun. All that additional energy has to go somewhere. Some of it warms the air. Most of it ends up in the oceans. All over the world, the oceans are getting warmer." 
Very well said. Nothing is over dramatized in presentation, and everything is pure science. No spin necessary.

Is there climate change?  Yes.  Is it man made?  Part of it yes.  Is the planet retaining more energy?  Yes.

Is the environmentalist platform partisan?  Yes.  Are there environmentalists who push alarmist viewpoints into the discussion?  Yes.  Has there been political modifications to climate change data in the past?  Yes.

Know the issues and the people with issues (Climate Deniers, Environmental Wackos, Politically motivated persons etc.) and you can be a more informed steward of the environment.  Ignore those people who pollute the discussion on climate change and maybe give the more moderate level headed people the reigns in the debate and we can get somewhere.

author: Gord Wait

text:
We understand climate and forcing mechanisms well enough to be able to analyse current factors driving the warming. None of the natural drivers (especially the sun and volcanoes) have been forcing energy accumulation in the earth system over the past 50 odd years, the opposite in fact. The only driver for warmth has been anthropogenic emissions.
And we know quite well what caused the glacial/interglacial cycles, being a feedback mechanism between Milankovic cycles and greenhouse gases. Guess what, we are in an unusual stage where the Milankovic cycles line up to ensure another 10,000 to 20,000 years of our current interglacial. So our greenhouse gases are not going to benefit us by staving off a glacial stage as some deniers would like.
As for science getting 'corrupted': every single endeavour of science is accused of that by some ideology, be it evolution, big bang, plate tectonics, vaccines, genetic engineering, nuclear energy, etc. I suggest you go back to basics and analyse why you probably accept the science on those topics, but happen to know better than the scientists on global warming.

Little ice ages happen approx every 150years, which means one should appear within the next 15-20years, so you could argue that the earth is warming (due to human emmissions), but there are MORE factors that account for warming/cooling (be it geomagnetic field, vegetation etc). The earth is complicated and you can't just say that human carbon emissions are the only factor. It's a TINY factor in a BIG equation. I would recommend reading up on Randall Carlson. We don't know what causes the warming, we need to research this more and in the mean time, let's focus on reducing pollution related health issues and not "saving our planet", because no matter what, the climate will change. Earth warms and cools naturally. Unfortunately I am no expert, so my reasoning could be false, but I wholeheartetly believe there is more to earths warming than human emissions

text: @d0p3t  To say that the earth goes through cycles that we don't understand is a cop-out. We can say that car wrecks happen at random, and they tend to go through cycles at certain times of the day, week, and year. Now what if every driver is given a bottle of vodka, and suddenly wrecks start to increase for some unknown reason? Is it genuine to say that since we can't stop wrecks from happening anyway, there's no need to worry about all the vodka we're handing out? There is a science behind how much heat can be trapped by CO2. It's not just a guess or some kind of evil theory being postulated by people looking for money. And besides, why do you only worry about money interests on ONE side of the debate and not the other? Is there no money at stake on the other side as well? THAT money is the only reason global warming is still a "debate" and not a fact accepted by everyone. Scientists don't have to promote global warming in order to receive pay checks. text:
@Synonymicon 
I never said that those deaths aren't a tragedy, but face the fact the such tsunamis are rare and local events. On the other hand, sea level rise from AGW will exacerbate the effect: a sea level rise of less than half a meter will allow such a tsunami to travel kilometers more inland, and thus cause thousands more deaths.
Renewable energy is not being developed or deployed at a significant rate by just the market alone; the increase in the past couple decades is largely due to the incentives and laws developed by governments. And largely in response to the advice from scientists.
A "geological blink of the eye" is irrelevant here, as we are talking about humans and society. A major global catastrophe only needs to last for a year or two for most modern societies to irreparably collapse. We are all geared for constant availability from across the world of essential goods on a weekly, at most monthly basis, and no reserves exist to carry us over for years. In that sense your nuclear holocaust is the most realistic challenger to AGW - and climate shifts will probably see nation aggression rise, and thus the likelihood of nuclear deployment. A disease pandemic is also af great concern, and AGW again has the capacity to worsen the spread and evolution of nasty diseases.
I don't even know what to make of 'social decay'

text:
No doubt climate is changing and is seemingly warming.

The question is what part of that is due to human involvement and what part of that is natural? This is the question the 'climate change' guys don't like to escalate.

Another question is even if human contribution to the climate change is substantial is that really a very bad thing? We've heard talks of various cities (e.g. London) being 'under water' in 'x number of years' if climate will keep warming. Really? What about flood barriers and various other measures that are used to stop water in numerous places all around the world? The Netherlands? Anyone? That country should have long been under water right? But ist's not. We should refrain from using sensational statements which will almost certainly NOT become reality regardless of whether we stop affecting the climate or not.

Don't get me wrong I'm not advocating the idea that climate change is not happening. It is happening. I just want to see a full picture with a full spectrum of issues being addressed and not just part of it. Therefore scientists who keep on 'demolishing' the global warming skeptics should apply a wider thought than just stating the fact that warming is happening. There are more questions such as how, why and how is that ACTUALLY going to affect us instead of just predicting unrealistic Armageddon scenarios.

author: ginckgo

text: @Avenrei  We can burn all the fuel we want and have the forests burn off in a cataclysm and it makes no difference in deep time.  The carbon cycle will keep right on churning recycling everything.  Meanwhile, life goes on.  What that life looks like and the habitat it lives in means nothing.  We suffer from the impatience of our mortality imposing and expecting homeostasis when it clearly does not exist.  Consider the larger narrative, that environmental change is constant, irresistible and irreversible vs. environmental change being manageable.  The latter narrative is appealing for our short lifespans, and assuaging any alarm we feel about environmental change, but little more.  Continents will drift, coastlines will change, ice ages will come and go.  My garden will end up in a moraine thousands of KM south of here come next ice age.  Oh well.  Ever stood in a clearcut a few years after the forest was cut down?  It's all scrubby growth and new trees planted by the loggers.  Ever stood in a clearcut a few hundred years after the forest was cut down?  I have, and you can't tell it had been cut without a history lesson or soil sample.  That it was cut in the first place just doesn't matter.  How people felt about it then and now, utterly meaningless.  The forest doesn't know and can't care.  As to climatology, I compare it to economics because it is descriptive, not predictive.

text:
@428ghost 
Mmm... philosophy major?
"The carbon cycle will keep right on churning recycling everything". You know the carbon cycle and you know that plants play an important role in said carbon cycle. Your assertion is that if we set all combustible carbon into the air, nature will find a way to balance it out. But have you considered the effects of climate change. Both of us agree climate changes. But what you are saying is that it doesn't matter what we do, climate changes. And I agree, change is the only constant. But we have accelerated this change which likes the world may only experience once before us and that change almost wiped out all of life, Permian extinction event.

And each time Earth plays this game of Russian Roulette, it runs the chance of going into a runaway scenario, like Mars, thereby extinguishing the only known life in the universe.

mmm... Regarding, the garden and cut forest examples, there are ways to tell. Trees for example, as they age, they grow rings. If a forest (primary forest) was cut and later regrown (secondary forest), its plants would always be younger than compared to the nearby forest that was not cut. While ideologically, you seem to try to connect to the natural order of things, you have failed to see the bigger picture designed into the smaller actions. Our natural will to survive. Your statements seem to suggest, you don't really care if the human race survives as nature will endure. But you have forgotten that all things in nature will and should try its best to live on and protect its own habitats. But correct me if you find my statements flawed. I like to see something different.
author: Avenrei
ginckgo

text:
Suffice to say I'm not one to become excited because I'm told I should be excited.  Perspective is needed to asses what is at stake.  Alarm over change when change is constant strikes me as imprudent.  The exponential function of change is imperceptible until the change occurs, then we all look back and tell ourselves we saw it coming.  When we do perceive change we're already at the turning point.  So what? 
 
We've identified instability within a complex system, climate.  Is it an instability?  Is not instability a condition of a complex system like climate?  Is this then a risk we need to factor for in our life decicsions?  Geology can tell us where major geological events will occur and why, but not when.  Within a cycle based on evidence we get an estimate.  By those estimates the west coast of the U,S. is overdue for a very bad day and Yellowstone National Park and the midwest more so.  Perhaps depleting aquifers and various mining activities are potential inputs adding to that instability.  So what?  We're in a cycle that existed long before men set foot in those place, the events will happen regardless of any factors we introduce.  In deep time any cessation of our activity is utterly meaningless.  In human time even less so because the probability of these events occuring during a human lifetime are slim.  It doesn't factor for life decisions.  People have, will and will continue to life in those places.  Even when an event occurs, they will adapt.
 
The same goes for climatic changes.  We will adapt.  We're in an inter-glacial period and overdue for the next ice age.  I live right in the path, but I know I won't see it.  I'd hate to see my children experience it, or my grand-kids, but my ties to the future beyond two generations gets pretty tenuous.  My ties to past generations more so.  They don't factor for my life decisions.  I'll live and die, the quickening or slowing of events in the span between I'll adapt to like everyone else.  Everything you do, including nothing at all, will have you arrive at your final destination.

Nobody's saying that life on earth will end, only life as we know it.  Civilizations, like so many species throughout our planets brief cosmological history, have come and gone in the blink of an eye, and it is mere conceit that convinces us we are somehow immune to the forces of nature.  If we value the future of our species we would do well to exercise that wondrous skill fine-tuned over eons of evolution: the ability to perceive, anticipate and plan for the worst.  In this instance yes, the planet will survive our activities, but the science is alarmingly clear that our species likely will not.  Unless you're some manner of sociopath, misanthropist, nihilist or conspiracy theorist, even you must see the wisdom in honestly assessing the current state of our environment and our relationship with it, and so doing act accordingly.

text:
@428ghost 
Have you been paying any attention in lectures?!? SO2 is not a GHG, it actually acts to cool (at least short term) by being highly reflective and nucleating cloud formation.
Also, you assert that warm spikes in the past have been short lived, which is blatantly wrong. Greenhouse climates can persist for many millions of years, and they are always associated with elevated GHGs. Even if there are the short hot spikes, like at the end Permian or the Palaeocen/Eocene Thermal Maximum, they are highly detrimental to life and cause mass extinctions.
My guess is that you went into your course with a preconceived world view, and you only heard what you wanted to hear to confirm it. Talk about "destructive ideological principles devoid of ethics and reason".
author: ginckgo

text: @ginckgo  The periods you cite are pre-Panamanian Isthmus.  The gulf stream effect changed the feedback loop preventing another runaway warming period and replaced it with glacial cycles.  If that quirk of geology weren't there you'd be right, but unless the Panamanian Isthmus suddenly vanishes the gulf stream effect will have a major dampening effect on global warm/cool cycles greater than individual GHG inputs.  And extinction is never a bad thing because it creates new environmental niches and promotes speciation.  Us?  I think you underestimate the survival advantage our tool making adaptation gives us.  We've already survived one extinction level event from the Toba eruption 70,000 years ago.  Considering our population size and technology, our ability to weather selecting environmental change is quite robust.
author: 428ghost

text:
@428ghost  So many things wrong there:
The Gulf Stream is a fickle thing, and has decreased of switched off numerous times over the past few million years.
Also, the timing of the closure of the Panama Isthmus (almost 10 Ma) is wrong as a major reason for the current Ice Age (starts about 2.5Ma); how does that reconcile with the mid-Pliocene warm period?
Yes, the Milankovic cycles have a more significant effect on climate swings during our Ice Age than during past warmer climates, however, the swings would not be nearly as dramatic without the feedback from GHGs. And right now we are independently adding GHGs at rates not seen probably since the Palaeocene/Eocene event.
Extinction not  a bad thing? WTF? We're not talking about background rates here, we're talking about mass extinction level rates, and depending on how severe the causes are, it can take more than a million years for ecosystems to recover; in the case of the Late Permian, it took 10 million years before biodiversity was anywhere near what it had been.
And mass extinction do not necessarily promote speciation, as some events (eg the late Devonian) were probably mass-depletion events, i.e. the extinction rate didn't increase, but the speciation rate plummeted.
And the new species the replace the old may not be at all what humans will find useful for us.
Human ingenuity is indeed great, and has gotten us out of a few muddles. Problem is that our societies and technologies are now so sophisticated that the whole edifice is actually much more fragile than it was just a century ago. If there is some level of catastrophe that knocks out a lot of infrastructure globally, especially the energy grid, it will be almost impossible to get ourselves out of it, as evereything is dependent on easy supply of materials. And considering all the low-hanging fruits of energy and resources are gone, humanity may permanently be stuck back in the bronze age.

text: If your premise even remotely rang true then the scientific enterprise would be an ubiquitously distrusted, derided and ridiculed discipline, naturally rife with swaths of corrupt opportunist alarmists regularly operating disingenuous chicken-little rackets propping up all manner of unfounded, portentous fire and brimstone claims of looming catastrophe based on utterly junk data, with a manufactured  "consensus" motivated by little more than petty and desperate grabs for funding.  That doesn't sound like science, however, that sounds like politics, and it seems to me you've somehow erroneously conflated the two.  Anyone who literally thinks this is by any means an accurate portrayal of the contemporary scientific community either  A) is not an actual, literate practicing scientist or B) doesn't know or has never worked directly with any scientists proper.  People who are motivated by money and are willing to bend the truth when it's profitable go on to get degrees in business or politics: that's where the money is.  People who care passionately about the truth and unveiling the actual nature of our universe go into the sciences.  The kind of disingenuous scientific charlatans you refer to would necessarily be few and far between: they would rarely, if ever survive the rigors of academia and the lofty standards undergirding the scientific discipline.  Such surreptitiously-motivated "bad eggs", whom you seem convinced are running the show, don't even walk onto the stage; they barely pass the intellectual hurdles laid before them at the beginning of the career path, and so lacking technical aptitude, interest or passion move on to more agreeable climes.  To suggest the discipline is so vulnerable to petty, selfish, monied interest that an ENTIRE scientific community around the ENTIRE world would twist circumstances to their advantage is not only ridiculous, but betrays either an uncharitable ignorance, a hapless misunderstanding or the mechanisms of a fiercely self-preserving ideological fundamentalism.

text:
@RedZeshinX  To some degree, you just wrote the historiography of science.  I had to laugh at this with remorse for how much it rang true.  However, you do set up a straw man with your hyperbole.  Science will only be as good as its practitioners, who are human and fallible.  The same holds for any human endeavour.  Science has no politics, but people do.  No academic discipline is so sacrosanct in its aims that it is somehow divorced from the human condition.  I know you're overstating your case to make a point, but the picture you paint of scientists as an inviolable class of people above self interest sounds disquietingly religious in tone.  I just say they're as self interested as the rest of humanity and will seize opportunities accordingly.

text: No discipline is inviolable.  However, the very essence of science is a questioning and skeptical disposition.  Science doesn't happen in a vacuum: a core component of its practice lies in subjecting findings to scrutiny, independent corroboration, verification and validation.    It is highly pessimistic to presume that internationally over 80 countries worth of scientific academies and over 95% of practicing climate scientists are ALL victims of funding-hungry human foible.  Even the most salient and vocal skeptics, such as Dr. Richard Muller, personally invested themselves into debunking contemporary climate science and were instead irrevocably persuaded of its reality.  Your skepticism is appreciably healthy, but your premise that the cart is universally before the horse is disagreeably unrealistic.
