author: 428ghost
ginckgo

text:
@ginckgo  Since 1998 there's a divergence between projections and data where we're experiencing a warming plateau in the data.  Refer to the 2013 IPCC chap 9 on models (1861-2014 data from the UK Met Office for example).  Getting back to my original post comparing climatology to economics, it's the models used that I'm getting at in terms of them being dreadful at predictions.  

Climatology faces the same problem economics faces: complexity.  Economics models, in particular from the Keynesian school of thought, have a dreadful record of setting forecasts.  They don't call it the dismal science just because of the subject, their projections are dismal!  Climatology, like economics, cannot capture all the details of the underlying system they're trying to model leaving them to approximate.  As such, small changes can bugger the fidelity of the model equations.  Slight changes in how elements of these systems are represented yield disproportionate results making the overall model inaccurate and therefore giving us predictions that fall flat.  Over, and over again.  Garbage in, garbage out, or more precisely, the model turns the data to garbage.

Climatology is essentially using the wrong instrument to model a complex system.  Climate models use differential equations, which by nature require known knowns to deal with deterministic values.  Such a model cannot factor for randomness and non-deterministic relationship between variables.  Economic models have historically used differential equations and their failure to predict generally leaves them the butt of jokes from the university math department, or so a computer scientist tells me.  Complexity theory is the baby of chaos theory and is harder to model (using network theory for example) than differential equations.  It does not have precise predictive value for forecasts of complex systems and cannot provide attribution, only pattern predictions.  Both climatology and economics are using equations derived from simple phenomenon like physics and applying them to complex phenomenon.  Square peg, round hole.  We can build bigger and better super-computers to run these models and just arrive at errors faster.

Both sciences contribute to policy decisions for governments.  Decision makers want precise, actionable results, and being human are susceptible to the the priming effect of interpreting data according to some preconceived model.  People will see what they want out of white noise.  Factor for herd behaviour to overcome decision fatigue and its easy to see how politicians get on the bandwagon supporting the policy de jour.  It all leads to bad decision making.  Models of climate forecasts are integrated into economic models to forecast the social cost of climate change.  An overstatement of climate inputs from a differential equation (unable to factor for complexity), entered into another differential equation (still unable to factor for complexity), leads to a vast over estimate of social costs to inform policy decisions.  When those ill informed decisions affect the management of limited global energy resources we're needlessly imposing major social costs before climate ever will.

If we get both disciplines to remodel based on complexity theory we may very well save the world from the politicians at least!

author: clayton Underwood

text:
"The question is what part of that is due to human involvement and what part of that is natural? This is the question the 'climate change' guys don't like to escalate." => Actually they do. We know how much carbon dioxide we are putting into the air. In fact scientist do a great deal in estimating green house gases from natural sources too. Next time a volcano erupts, read the estimates of scale of it. We also know that we are currently the largest producers of carbon dioxide, consider the fact that we populate the entire world, we are most definitely affecting the climate. Don't believe me? Read BBC on "Weekends are wetter". A cliff note is that our weekly schedule actually affects the probability of rain.

To answer another question:
Well, whilst there are benefits in the climate getting warmer (i.e the nordic sea route opening, shortening time and cost of transporting goods), generally we should worry about climate changes and rising sea levels. Remember, we as a race gain dominance when the climate was as it was. Change may not bode well for us, higher on the food chain. To understand this, lets put one example, u may need to read up on. That is the undersea current. It is cause by the difference in temperatures between the water. Should our oceans warm up enough, this temperature difference may not be sufficient to circulate the ocean, causing an increase in build of hydrogen sulphate, poisoning the sea and hence one of our major food source, fish. Even without waiting so long, Fishes as our food source is already compromised by the sudden increase in Jellyfish population which is said to strive due to the increase heat and pollution

Furthermore, while I do not doubt human tenacity to survive adversity, I ask: Do you really want to reach the point of adversity before you change? To have flood defenses, sounds great. But you must understand one thing about flood defenses, it only needs to fail in a single area to cause major catastrophe. Read up on Hurricane Katrina, Levee failure. Ironically, part of the reason why hurricanes causes more damage now is also attributed to the lost of mangrove swamps near the hurricane's path which originally help lower its potency.

If you are genuinely interested in how it affects us, my advice is to actually read up on the world in a neutral position. Throw that notion of "is something true" and read it without bias. Then assess the information and see if you have a conclusion. My understanding did not stem from proving climate deniers wrong but just the general interest in how the world works. And it isn't hard to find the truth that we humans have to really worry about climate change.
author: Avenrei

text:
@*****   I think that whilst scientist, being specialized in that field of knowledge would hold greater credence on the subject matter of science. I think that the most wonderful thing about science is that you do not have to be a scientist to question science. It doesn't work on credential or position. But facts, verifiable and repeatable.

So even if a beggar makes a valid observation which could disprove a major scientist, science will (and must) side with the one that is right.

I think that by name-calling, we may actually disenfranchise the general population from taking up scientific pursuits which if you consider, is rather ironic. Considering that science is afterall the accumulation of verifiable knowledge by the human race.

Instead, I beseech you to try to look at each of those who question science as a bright eyed kid who is looking at the world for the first time. And whose interest is genuine. Only if presented with irrefutable evidence that they still insist in illogical ways, do we give up hope on them and pursue greater knowledge for our self-improvement.

text:
@urban dweller  Your OP tries to cast doubt on all the fundamental science that is now established:
- human emissions having any impact ("The question is what part of that is due to human involvement and what part of that is natural?")
the fact that on average it will be damaging to humans societies and economies ("even if human contribution to the climate change is substantial is that really a very bad thing?")
- That sea level rise is significant ("That country should have long been under water right? But ist's not.")
- The fact that climate scientist have already thought of, and researched, all the 'skeptic' talking points ("scientists who keep on 'demolishing' the global warming skeptics should apply a wider thought than just stating the fact that warming is happening")
- and now you say there is "clear evidence or clear declaration that there is no evidence for some of those issues."
I know you probably genuinely think you believe in science and are genuinely skeptical, but at this point you are just sounding like all the other boring deniers.

text:
@urban dweller 
You can't have really gone in search of the answers, and they generally have been obfuscated by the deniers anyway. They bleat about being silenced, but actually get their ideas across very well, thanks to media owned by corporations who have a vested interest in keeping the facts of AGW from being clearly expressed. Read 'The Discovery Of Global Warming' by Spencer Weart and subscribe to realclimate [dot] org or skepticalscience [dot] com – sites run by scientists not TV weathermen or journalists/lawyers/chartered accountants. The latter has a handy guide to climate myths propagated by the deniers, and answers to those fallacies.

author: Autumn Windwalker

text: @urban dweller  What are the implications of global warming? We just passed the extremely dangerous 400 parts per million of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere (it was at 278 ppm before the industrial revolution). We are zooming towards the tipping point at which the average temperature on the planet will increase to that point that ecosystems will collapse, famine will be rampant, acidization will occur in the oceans causing the destruction of a large portion of oceanic life, groundwater supply dries up, etc. Obviously these are catastrophic events that nearly EVERY single scientific expert in the field is warning us will happen. People can choose to ignore the warnings but at great peril to our future.
author: Brian Tyler

text:
Honestly, various cities being under water aren't really of a huge concern to me in the long-run. What does worry me is the famine. The hardest hit will be the places where food is already difficult to grow, but we'll go from being able to feed our population (and then some) to barely scraping by. Hundreds of millions of people will die.

If not from famine, then from drought, or more powerful storms, or more ravaging fires.

And for what? So we can keep burning fuels that gives us asthma and cancer. That darken our skies and poison our water. That we have to get by paying billions of dollars to foreign governments whose citizens want to undo our very society. That we have to protect our interests in by starting wars and involving ourselves in every conflict.

There are many alternatives, and those alternatives have done nothing but get better and better in the last 50 years. We could easily be off of fossil fuels at this point in history. So why wouldn't we make that change?

author: urban dweller

text:
@urban dweller  You sound like you are open to learning about the science of global warming, but you have been misinformed about the facts.

Scientists have already extensively studied the questions you asked. Many thousands of dedicated experts have spent decades researching these and other related questions. Over 97% are convinced that the evidence is overwhelming, leaving extremely little doubt about the causes and impacts of Anthropomorphic Global Warming. Specific details are debated, such as how quickly the oceans will rise, but not the broad picture, the fact that the oceans will rise.

Human activity is the cause for global warming.
We are already experiencing the impacts.
They will become significantly worse, soon. 
It is already too late to prevent this.
They will become catastrophic in the longer term if we do not take significant action soon.

If the only impact was the rising oceans, then we could deal with it, at significant cost. In fact, that will be the least of our problems. The rain forests are already experiencing significant heat stress. The US west is enduring the worst drought since the 1930's. Many areas in the world suffer from extreme flooding from historically heavy rainfalls. Hurricanes have increased in intensity. All of these will increase in frequency.

Most likely, the most severe problem will be widespread crop failures, leading to massive famines that having not been experienced in the developed world in centuries. Millions of people will die, unless we take action. That is the reality, not hyperbole. There is extensive evidence, confirmed by hundreds of thousands of observations.
author: Eric14492

text: @urban dweller  Not at all. Scientists can extrapolate accurate predictive models from the evidence. This is done all the time in science. The thousands upon thousands of geologists, physicists, and atmospheric scientists giving these warnings aren't "guessing." The scientific findings revealed from various scientific fields from thousands of researchers from over all of the world are a chorus of unambiguous uniformity. They are stating what happens when the carbon dioxide levels get past a certain point and it is supported by reams of research and evidence. Anyone can simply assert the very experts in their field are ALL wrong but the difference is they have evidence to support their scientific models findings. It would be wise to heed their warnings.
author: Brian Tyler

text:
@Eric14492  All of this is mendable. Crops have gone up in productivity by TIMES over the past few decades thanks to fertilizers, GMO and other new technologies. Hurricanes and such are trivial in the face of modern infrastructure. Just look at earthquakes and how countries like Japan (or even the US) have dealt with it. It is essentially not a problem for a modern society with modern infrastructure and supply chains. 

This is the problem I was talking about. Despite the facts that we know for sure (that warming IS happening or even that it IS mainly due to human input) there are some slippery areas which are subject to wild interpretations based on nothing but projections based on very different inputs by different people. I mean do you really think there will be "massive famines" anywhere in the world due to climate change? Probably not.
author: urban dweller

text:
@Valendr0s  Famine? Hundreds of millions dead? Really? And you DO have a scientific explanation to that right? You DO realize that in a modern society goods (including food) move on motorways, railways and cargo ships. It is not a problem to feed a population of MILLIONS which is THOUSANDS of kilometers away from the nearest food source. This is what you get from modern transport system. Same with water supply. Even today people live in areas which were not suitable for habitat couple of hundred years ago purely because of modern transport. Unless the entire earth will become infertile and not suitable for vegetation? For this to happen you would need a nuclear WW3 at the very least.

The reality is that there is TOO MUCH food in the world nowadays. It is easier than ever to move it around FAST. In fact, it is not a problem to move frozen meat from New Zealand to China these days. Or the most delicate foods across the globe while keeping it fresh. It is absolutely nonsensical to predict famine because of global warming.
author: urban dweller

text: @urban dweller  It is really really basic. The earth exists on a knife edge called the "goldilocks zone" where if the average global temperature changes by a very small amount in either direction, life on earth will cease to exist. In an extremely small amount of time mankind has caused the temperature to increase through carbon dioxide increases in the atmosphere causing the greenhouse effect. If this continues there will become a point where we would wipe out life as we know it. Nearly every scientists on earth says this. Are you the world's most brilliant geologist, physicist, and atmospheric scientist rolled into one that can overturn ALL of the scientific data and research? I simply don't get the deniers.
